top_comment.text:
Take the time to watch tonight's #TChat guest +Todd Dewett  in action and 
you will understand why I'm so excited about talking with him today.  Todd 
relates a story about an executive who learned that his team is not a 
reflection of himself but made up of extraordinary people.  On #TChat this 
evening +Kevin W. Grossman  and I will have the chance to learn more about 
how  leaders can "get over themselves" and be more effective by being more 
authentic.  In line with that is the latest post from +Nancy Rubin about 
the personal and professional benefits of becoming self-aware.

 
http://www.talentculture.com/leadership/leaders-with-authenticity-spark-company-electricity/. 
 

*Join us tonight from **6:30**pm ET on BlogTalkRadio and 7-8 pm ET on 
Twitter.*

#TChat   #authenticity   #leadership   #authenticleadership  ﻿
top_comment.author: Meghan M. Biro

comments.text:
+Nancy Rubin you make me want to read more before the chat! Once you see +Dr. 
Todd Dewett in action, you won't want to miss this chat.
comments.author: Lori Anding King

comments.text:
I agree +Libby Baker Sweiger Leadership should be seen as a privilege not a 
right and used to inspire those around them.
comments.author: Emilie Mecklenborg

comments.text:
We all need to "get over ourselves" but especially leaders, agreed! "Close 
your mouth open your ears and see the amazing people all around you"! LOVE 
IT!
comments.author: Libby Baker Sweiger

captions.text:
You know, success in life isn't 
so much about what you know.

It really is about what you do 
with what you know.

You see, knowledge between 
your ears is about potential.

But it's not really 
value-added until you share it,
make those connections, and share it.
And that's where the tragedy starts.

We far too often waste knowledge. 
You know why?
Because we're not nice enough,
we're not likeable enough,

we're not open, 
we're not agreeable enough,

we don't make ourselves 
someone others can relate to,
and that's unfortunate.

So we have to learn 
to get over ourselves.
Leaders, experts, hear me.

You've got to get down off 
of that pedestal sometimes,

put two feet on the ground, 
close your mouth,
open your ears, use your eyes,
and see the amazing people around you

for the unique individuals they are, 
and the value they add.

And when you do, it's amazing how much 
more interesting they might find you.
And that's when knowledge gets shared,

great relationships are born, 
great teams begin.

Now, I met a guy years ago who learned 
this lesson in an interesting way.

I'm in class, I'm teaching 
a course years ago,

one of my students, guy's name's Dave, 
raised his hand like this.
Now in my class this is funny,

nobody would ever raise their hand, 
we just talked.

But he was polite, old-school young 
40-something executive,
he raised his hand and we loved it,

because we knew 
when Dave raised his hand,

well we were gonna hear 
something interesting.

He was thoughtful. And he said: 
"Well look Doc, I hear ya."

"I want everyone here to know, 
I agree with you."

But..." –big pause– he says:
"I want them to realize

it's so much more difficult to go to work 
with real people and get stuff right

than it is to sit here in a classroom, 
and just talk about it."
And I said, "You know, you're right."

He goes, "Well, 
I messed that up recently.

I screwed up, I learned something, 
it's embarrassing.
I didn't want it to happen, but it did.

I figured, maybe I'd share it 
with the class"

and you guys would avoid 
the same mistake I made."
I said, "That sounds great. Go for it."

He said, "Well, you all know I just got 
my first executive role ever.
I'm a leader of leaders.

Beneath me –this is his words, 
not mine– I have 20 code jockeys.

"These are people who are
expert computer programmers,
who each have teams below them.

He said, "I love these guys, and I knew 
the power of showing gratitude

and being thankful when they 
really earned it, and so I waited"

he said that, "and 
I waited for a month or two

until real milestones piled up 
worthy of thanking, and applauding.

And unannounced, I walked out 
into their cubes at work

and I called everybody over 
for a big huddle.

I didn't tell them why, just said 
'everybody come out here!'
All the managers came out there, he said,

I took the knee like a good coach, and 
I got down there and I said real simply,
'You guys are doing great work. Thank you.

I wanna tell you how much I appreciate 
all the hard work that you're doing.

So, I'm going to take everybody 
on the team to Happy Hour."

Now, you drinkers in the crowd 
who just giggled,
like me, enjoy a good happy hour.

But you're also bright and 
you know not everyone does.

Couple of days later,
they went to Happy Hour.

There's Dave, waiting on the team. 
Half the team showed.

He was baffled to see 
only half of his team there.

Late that night, one guy left at the bar 
with Dave, someone he's known for a while,

who will give him straight feedback, 
he's a member of the team, and he said,

"Look, not everyone 
likes to drink pal, I'm sorry.
Oh by the way, people who came tonight

didn't show up to have a drink 
and a smile with the boss.

They came because they thought 
if they did not show up,

that somehow they were gonna 
lose points back at the office."

Dave found out that in trying 
to do something positive

he'd inadvertently created a negative 
outcome, and he was embarrassed.

This is not what he was 
used to as a professional.

Went back to the office, 
he was embarrassed

he couldn't look at people 
for a couple of days.

But he resolved to cook up 
some awesome thank you

for his team in the future
when they earn it

that would be so awesome, 
so powerful,

they would forget 
the odd happy hour incident.
(Laughter)
And he waited, and milestones piled up,

and when the time was 
right for a second time,

Dave waded out in the middle 
of all those cubes and offices
and called an unannounced huddle,

and everyone walked over like 
"Good God, here comes Happy Hour"
(Laughter)

and he said, 
down on one knee again, he said,

"Let me tell you guys, you're doing great 
work. You're making me look good.

I wanna show you how much 
I appreciate your hard work,

so I'm gonna take the 
whole group... canoeing."
(Laughter)

Can you imagine what these 
poor people were thinking?
(Laughter)
"Now I've gotta get sunburned with this idiot!"
(Laughter)
Couple weekends later, they went canoeing.

The same half a team showed up, 
almost to a person,

and the same guy gave 
Dave the same feedback,
saying "Pal, you just did the same thing!
Twice! But this time you ruined a weekend!"
(Laughter)

Dave had a professional crisis, 
he told class.

He had never felt this disconnected 
and aloof in a professional context.

He was very embarrassed, it took 
many days back at the office

before he could actually look 
them in the eyes once more.

He said, "I just sat there a lot, 
for hours, and I watched them,

right there, doing what they 
do in their natural habitat.

I just watched them. 
And finally, it hit me.

I broke through. I had
–what he called– an epiphany.

I realized that what I'd been doing 
this whole time was very simple.

I'd been doing nothing more 
than projecting me onto them.

That's all I was doing. 
Projecting me onto them."

He said to my class that night 
in a very confessional way,

"You know what, I like to drink. 
I like to canoe.

Very often, I like to drink 
while I'm canoeing."
(Laughter)
"And the breakthrough moment was

realizing that had
nothing to do with my team."

He said, "When I realized that, 
and a new lens clicked in place,

I saw something, 
right there in front of me.

It had been there every day, but I 
missed it every day until now. I saw it."

Everyone's hanging on his words 
in class, listening to this story.
I said, "what did you see?!"

He goes, "I noticed that every 
single person on my team,

every person, had a very clear 
indication in their workspace

that they were a huge fan 
of professional wrestling."
(Laughter)

"Bobble head, figurine, mousepad, 
screen saver, signed autograph."

Now Dave, like me, thought 
that professional wrestling

was about the stupidest 
thing man ever created.
(Laughter)

And he understood, which is so 
beautiful, how little that meant.

And the next time those folks had 
genuine things worth celebrating,

he, for a brave third time, walked down 
the middle of all those cubes and offices,

called the huddle, took a knee, 
and everyone's just "Oh God..."
(Laughter)

"He's gonna make us
jump out of airplanes?"
(Laughter)
He took the knee, he said,

"I'm gonna keep this short and sweet, 
thanks, you're doing great work."

BAM! He pulled out tickets 
to the freak show,

and the next weekend 
went with his team to see

the men in tights do their 
thing at the local coliseum.
(Laughter)
100% of the team showed up.

Dave said what happened 
that evening was really magical.

"They called me by my first name, 
comfortably, for the first time.
Hit me on the arm, pat me on the back,

looked me in the eye, 
comfortably, for the first time.

I could tell I was still the boss,"
he said,

but for the first time I was clearly 
also a member of the team.

Thank God! 
I learned to get over myself.

Thank God! 
I learned to get over myself.

I think that you and I can share 
that perspective with Dave,
and make it work for us as well.

I hope that's the perspective 
you'll take with you today,
'cause ladies and gentlemen,

you're about to see an amazing 
array of knowledge on display.
Enjoy this event. Thank you.

[Cheers]
[Applause]

title: Get over yourself! Todd Dewett at TEDxDayton
